trans-unit.source: Binary distributions are used to speed up the process of installing dependencies with binary components (like M2Crypto and LXML). Instead of recompiling these dependencies again for every virtual environment we compile them once and cache the result as a binary
trans-unit.target: Binary distributions are used to speed up the process of installing dependencies with binary components (like M2Crypto and LXML). Instead of recompiling these dependencies again for every virtual environment we compile them once and cache the result as a binary

trans-unit.source: Paylogic uses pip-accel to quickly and reliably initialize virtual environments on its farm of continuous integration slaves which are constantly running unit tests (this was one of the original use cases for which pip-accel was developed). We also use it on our build servers.
trans-unit.target: Paylogic uses pip-accel to quickly and reliably initialize virtual environments on its farm of continuous integration slaves which are constantly running unit tests (this was one of the original use cases for which pip-accel was developed). We also use it on our build servers.

trans-unit.source: Accelerator for pip, the Python package manager
trans-unit.target: Acelerador para pip,el gestor de paquetes de Python

trans-unit.target: Basándose en el usuario que ejecuta pip-accel,se utilizan por defecto las siguientes ubicaciones de archivos:

trans-unit.source: Because pip-accel caches compiled binary packages it can still provide a nice speed boost over using plain pip.
trans-unit.target: Debido a que los cachés de pip-aceleración compilaron paquetes binarios,todavía puede proporcionar un buen aumento de la velocidad en comparación con el uso de pip simple.

trans-unit.source: Both of these cache backends are registered with pip-accel using a generic pluggable cache backend registration mechanism. This mechanism makes it possible to register additional cache backends without modifying pip-accel. If you are interested in the details please refer to pip-accel’s
trans-unit.target: Both of these cache backends are registered with pip-accel using a generic pluggable cache backend registration mechanism. This mechanism makes it possible to register additional cache backends without modifying pip-accel. If you are interested in the details please refer to pip-accel’s

trans-unit.source: Bundled with pip-accel are a local cache backend (which stores distribution archives on the local file system) and an Amazon S3 backend (see below).
trans-unit.target: Bundled with pip-accel are a local cache backend (which stores distribution archives on the local file system) and an Amazon S3 backend (see below).

trans-unit.source: By using pip-accel you can make Python deployments completely independent from internet connectivity.
trans-unit.target: Usando pip-accel puedes hacer despliegues de Python completamente independientes de la conectividad a Internet.
Caching de los requisitos de configuración
Control del flujo de la pip-acel
Depende de los paquetes de sistemas

trans-unit.source: For most users the default configuration of pip-accel should be fine. If you do want to change pip-accel’s defaults you do so by setting environment variables and/or adding configuration options to a configuration file. This is because pip-accel shares its command line interface with pip and adding support for command line options specific to pip-accel is non trivial and may end up causing more confusion than it’s worth :-). For an overview of the available configuration options and corresponding environment variables please refer to the documentation of the pip_accel.config module.
trans-unit.target: For most users the default configuration of pip-accel should be fine. If you do want to change pip-accel’s defaults you do so by setting environment variables and/or adding configuration options to a configuration file. This is because pip-accel shares its command line interface with pip and adding support for command line options specific to pip-accel is non trivial and may end up causing more confusion than it’s worth :-). For an overview of the available configuration options and corresponding environment variables please refer to the documentation of the pip_accel.config module.

trans-unit.source: Here’s what it looks like in practice:
trans-unit.target: Here’s what it looks like in practice:

trans-unit.source: If the command fails it means that pip encountered errors while scanning PyPI, scanning a distribution website, downloading a source distribution or unpacking a source distribution. Usually these kinds of errors are intermittent so retrying a few times is worth a shot. Go to step 2.
trans-unit.target: If the command fails it means that pip encountered errors while scanning PyPI, scanning a distribution website, downloading a source distribution or unpacking a source distribution. Usually these kinds of errors are intermittent so retrying a few times is worth a shot. Go to step 2.

trans-unit.source: If the command fails it probably means not all dependencies are available as local source distributions yet so we should download them. Go to step 2.
trans-unit.target: Si el comando falla,probablemente significa que no todas las dependencias están disponibles como distribuciones de fuente local todavía,por lo que deberíamos descargarlas.Ve al paso 2.

trans-unit.source: If the command succeeds it means all dependencies are already available as downloaded source distributions. We’ll parse the verbose pip output of step 1 to find the direct and transitive dependencies (names and versions) defined in
trans-unit.target: If the command succeeds it means all dependencies are already available as downloaded source distributions. We’ll parse the verbose pip output of step 1 to find the direct and transitive dependencies (names and versions) defined in

trans-unit.source: If the command succeeds it means all dependencies are now available as local source distributions; we don’t need the network anymore! Go to step 1.
trans-unit.target: If the command succeeds it means all dependencies are now available as local source distributions; we don’t need the network anymore! Go to step 1.

trans-unit.source: If this option is set pip-accel will skip uploading to the Amazon S3 bucket. This means pip-accel will use the configured Amazon S3 bucket to “warm up” your local cache but it will never write to the bucket, so you can use read only credentials. Of course you will need to run at least one instance of pip-accel that does have write permissions, so this setup is best suited to teams working around e.g. a continuous integration (CI) server, where the CI server primes the cache and developers use the cache in read only mode.
trans-unit.target: If this option is set pip-accel will skip uploading to the Amazon S3 bucket. This means pip-accel will use the configured Amazon S3 bucket to “warm up” your local cache but it will never write to the bucket, so you can use read only credentials. Of course you will need to run at least one instance of pip-accel that does have write permissions, so this setup is best suited to teams working around e.g. a continuous integration (CI) server, where the CI server primes the cache and developers use the cache in read only mode.

trans-unit.source: If you have questions, bug reports, suggestions, etc. please create an issue on the GitHub project page. The latest version of pip-accel will always be available on GitHub. The internal API documentation is hosted on Read The Docs.
trans-unit.target: If you have questions, bug reports, suggestions, etc. please create an issue on the GitHub project page. The latest version of pip-accel will always be available on GitHub. The internal API documentation is hosted on Read The Docs.

trans-unit.source: If you’ve written a cache backend that you think may be valuable to others, please feel free to open an issue or pull request on GitHub in order to get your backend bundled with pip-accel.
trans-unit.target: If you’ve written a cache backend that you think may be valuable to others, please feel free to open an issue or pull request on GitHub in order to get your backend bundled with pip-accel.

trans-unit.source: In addition, since version 0.9 pip-accel contains a simple mechanism that detects missing system packages when a build fails and prompts the user whether to install the missing dependencies and retry the build.
trans-unit.target: Además,desde la versión 0.9 pip-accel contiene un sencillo mecanismo que detecta los paquetes de sistema que faltan cuando falla una compilación y le indica al usuario si debe instalar las dependencias que faltan y volver a intentar la compilación.

trans-unit.source: Install all dependencies from binary distributions based on the list of direct and transitive dependencies obtained in step 1. We have to do these installations manually because easy_install nor pip support binary
trans-unit.target: Instale todas las dependencias de las distribuciones binarias basándose en la lista de dependencias directas y transitivas obtenida en el paso 1.Tenemos que hacer estas instalaciones manualmente porque easy_install ni pip soporta binarios

trans-unit.source: Since version 0.38 pip-accel instructs setuptools to cache setup requirements in a subdirectory of pip-accel’s data directory (see the eggs_cache option) to avoid recompilation of setup requirements. This works by injecting a symbolic link called
trans-unit.target: Since version 0.38 pip-accel instructs setuptools to cache setup requirements in a subdirectory of pip-accel’s data directory (see the eggs_cache option) to avoid recompilation of setup requirements. This works by injecting a symbolic link called

trans-unit.source: Since version 0.9 pip-accel contains a simple mechanism that detects missing system packages when a build fails and prompts the user whether to install the missing dependencies and retry the build. Currently only Debian Linux and derivative Linux distributions are supported, although support for other platforms should be easy to add. This functionality currently works based on configuration files that define dependencies of Python packages on system packages. This means the results should be fairly reliable, but every single dependency needs to be manually defined…
trans-unit.target: Since version 0.9 pip-accel contains a simple mechanism that detects missing system packages when a build fails and prompts the user whether to install the missing dependencies and retry the build. Currently only Debian Linux and derivative Linux distributions are supported, although support for other platforms should be easy to add. This functionality currently works based on configuration files that define dependencies of Python packages on system packages. This means the results should be fairly reliable, but every single dependency needs to be manually defined…

trans-unit.source: Source distribution downloads are cached and used to generate a local index of source distribution archives. If all your dependencies are pinned to absolute versions whose source distribution downloads were previously cached, pip-accel won’t need a network connection at all! This is one of the reasons why pip can be so slow: given absolute pinned dependencies available in the download cache it will still scan PyPI and distribution websites.
trans-unit.target: Source distribution downloads are cached and used to generate a local index of source distribution archives. If all your dependencies are pinned to absolute versions whose source distribution downloads were previously cached, pip-accel won’t need a network connection at all! This is one of the reasons why pip can be so slow: given absolute pinned dependencies available in the download cache it will still scan PyPI and distribution websites.

trans-unit.target: Almacenamiento del caché binario en el Amazon S3

trans-unit.source: The optional prefix to apply to all Amazon S3 keys. This enables name spacing based on the environment in which pip-accel is running (to isolate the binary caches of ABI incompatible systems). The user is currently responsible for choosing a suitable prefix.
trans-unit.target: The optional prefix to apply to all Amazon S3 keys. This enables name spacing based on the environment in which pip-accel is running (to isolate the binary caches of ABI incompatible systems). The user is currently responsible for choosing a suitable prefix.

trans-unit.source: The pip-accel program is a wrapper for pip, the Python package manager. It accelerates the usage of pip to initialize Python virtual environments given one or more requirements files. It does so by combining the following two approaches:
trans-unit.target: The pip-accel program is a wrapper for pip, the Python package manager. It accelerates the usage of pip to initialize Python virtual environments given one or more requirements files. It does so by combining the following two approaches:

trans-unit.source: The pip-accel program is currently tested on cPython 2.6, 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5 and PyPy (2.7). The automated test suite regularly runs on Ubuntu Linux (Travis CI) as well as Microsoft Windows (AppVeyor). In addition to these platforms pip-accel should work fine on most UNIX systems (e.g. Mac OS X).
trans-unit.target: The pip-accel program is currently tested on cPython 2.6, 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5 and PyPy (2.7). The automated test suite regularly runs on Ubuntu Linux (Travis CI) as well as Microsoft Windows (AppVeyor). In addition to these platforms pip-accel should work fine on most UNIX systems (e.g. Mac OS X).

trans-unit.source: The way pip-accel works is not very intuitive but it is very effective. Below is an overview of the control flow. Once you take a look at the code you’ll notice that the steps below are all embedded in a loop that retries several times. This is mostly because of step 2 (downloading the source distributions).
trans-unit.target: The way pip-accel works is not very intuitive but it is very effective. Below is an overview of the control flow. Once you take a look at the code you’ll notice that the steps below are all embedded in a loop that retries several times. This is mostly because of step 2 (downloading the source distributions).

trans-unit.source: When pip-accel was originally developed PyPI was sometimes very unreliable (PyPI wasn’t behind a CDN back then). Because of the CDN, PyPI is much more reliable nowadays however pip-accel still has its place:

trans-unit.source: You can configure pip-accel to store its binary cache files in an Amazon S3 bucket. In this case Amazon S3 is treated as a second level cache, only used if the local file system cache can’t satisfy a dependency. If the dependency is not found in the Amazon S3 bucket, the package is built and cached locally (as usual) but then also saved to the Amazon S3 bucket. This functionality can be useful for continuous integration build worker boxes that are ephemeral and don’t have persistent local storage to store the pip-accel binary cache.
trans-unit.target: You can configure pip-accel to store its binary cache files in an Amazon S3 bucket. In this case Amazon S3 is treated as a second level cache, only used if the local file system cache can’t satisfy a dependency. If the dependency is not found in the Amazon S3 bucket, the package is built and cached locally (as usual) but then also saved to the Amazon S3 bucket. This functionality can be useful for continuous integration build worker boxes that are ephemeral and don’t have persistent local storage to store the pip-accel binary cache.

trans-unit.source: You can tell Tox to use pip-accel using a small shell script that first uses pip to install pip-accel, then uses pip-accel to bootstrap the virtual environment. You can find details about this in issue #30 on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: You can tell Tox to use pip-accel using a small shell script that first uses pip to install pip-accel, then uses pip-accel to bootstrap the virtual environment. You can find details about this in issue #30 on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: directory was added in setuptools version 7.0 which is why pip-accel now requires setuptools 7.0 or higher to be installed. This dependency was added because the whole point of pip-accel is to work well out of the box, shielding the user from surprising behavior like setup requirements slowing things down and breaking offline installation.
